exam_description: 2nd & Final Public Release with Errata - March 15, 2019

question_pool.question: On which HF/MF bands is a General class license holder granted all amateur frequency privileges?

answers.C: 160 meters, 60 meters, 30 meters, 17 meters, 12 meters, and 10 meters
answers.D: 160 meters, 30 meters, 17 meters, 15 meters, 12 meters, and 10 meters

question_pool.question: On which of the following bands is phone operation prohibited?
On which of the following bands is image transmission prohibited?
Which of the following amateur bands is restricted to communication only on specific channels, rather than frequency ranges?
Which of the following frequencies is in the General class portion of the 40-meter band in ITU Region 2?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 75-meter phone band?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 20-meter phone band?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 80-meter band?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 15-meter band?
Which of the following frequencies is available to a control operator holding a General class license?
When General class licensees are not permitted to use the entire voice portion of a band, which portion of the voice segment is generally available to them?

answers.C: The lower frequency end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz, and the upper end on frequencies above 14.150 MHz
answers.D: The upper frequency end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz, and the lower end on frequencies above 14.150 MHz

question_pool.question: Which of the following applies when the FCC rules designate the Amateur Service as a secondary user on a band?

answers.A: Amateur stations must record the call sign of the primary service station before operating on a frequency assigned to that station
answers.B: Amateur stations can use the band only during emergencies
answers.C: Amateur stations can use the band only if they do not cause harmful interference to primary users
answers.D: Amateur stations may only operate during specific hours of the day, while primary users are permitted 24- hour use of the band

question_pool.question: What is the appropriate action if, when operating on either the 30-meter or 60-meter bands, a station in the primary service interferes with your contact?

answers.A: Notify the FCCs regional Engineer in Charge of the interference
answers.B: Increase your transmitter’s power to overcome the interference
answers.C: Attempt to contact the station and request that it stop the interference
answers.D: Move to a clear frequency or stop transmitting

question_pool.question: Which of the following may apply in areas under FCC jurisdiction outside of ITU Region 2?

answers.A: Station identification may have to be in a language other than English
answers.B: Morse code may not be permitted
answers.C: Digital transmission may not be permitted

question_pool.question: What portion of the 10-meter band is available for repeater use?

answers.B: The portion between 28.1 MHz and 28.2 MHz
answers.C: The portion between 28.3 MHz and 28.5 MHz

question_pool.question: What is the maximum height above ground to which an antenna structure may be erected without requiring notification to the FAA and registration with the FCC, provided it is not at or near a public use airport?
With which of the following conditions must beacon stations comply?

answers.A: A beacon station may not use automatic control
answers.B: The frequency must be coordinated with the National Beacon Organization
answers.C: The frequency must be posted on the internet or published in a national periodical
answers.D: There must be no more than one beacon signal transmitting in the same band from the same station location

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a purpose of a beacon station as identified in the FCC rules?

answers.C: Transmission of bulletins of general interest to Amateur Radio licensees

question_pool.question: Which of the following transmissions is permitted?

answers.A: Unidentified transmissions for test purposes only
answers.B: Retransmission of other amateur station signals by any amateur station
answers.C: Occasional retransmission of weather and propagation forecast information from U.S. government stations
answers.D: Coded messages of any kind, if not intended to facilitate a criminal act

question_pool.question: Which of the following one-way transmissions are permitted?

answers.A: Unidentified test transmissions of less than one minute in duration
answers.B: Transmissions necessary to assist learning the International Morse code
answers.C: Regular transmissions offering equipment for sale, if intended for Amateur Radio use

question_pool.question: Under what conditions are state and local governments permitted to regulate Amateur Radio antenna structures?

answers.A: Under no circumstances, FCC rules take priority
answers.B: At any time and to any extent necessary to accomplish a legitimate purpose of the state or local entity, provided that proper filings are made with the FCC
answers.C: Only when such structures exceed 50 feet in height and are clearly visible 1000 feet from the structure
answers.D: Amateur Service communications must be reasonably accommodated, and regulations must constitute the minimum practical to accommodate a legitimate purpose of the state or local entity

question_pool.question: What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the Amateur Service?

answers.B: They may be used if they do not obscure the meaning of a message

question_pool.question: When choosing a transmitting frequency, what should you do to comply with good amateur practice?

answers.A: Ensure that the frequency and mode selected are within your license class privileges
answers.B: Follow generally accepted band plans agreed to by the Amateur Radio community

question_pool.question: On what HF frequencies are automatically controlled beacons permitted?

answers.A: On any frequency if power is less than 1 watt
answers.B: On any frequency if transmissions are in Morse code

question_pool.question: What is the power limit for beacon stations?
Who or what determines “good engineering and good amateur practice,” as applied to the operation of an amateur station in all respects not covered by the Part 97 rules?
When is it permissible to communicate with amateur stations in countries outside the areas administered by the Federal Communications Commission?

answers.A: Only when the foreign country has a formal third-party agreement filed with the FCC
answers.B: When the contact is with amateurs in any country except those whose administrations have notified the ITU that they object to such communications
answers.C: When the contact is with amateurs in any country as long as the communication is conducted in English
answers.D: Only when the foreign country is a member of the International Amateur Radio Union

question_pool.question: What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on 10.140 MHz?
What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on the 12-meter band?

answers.D: An effective radiated power equivalent to 100 watts from a half-wave dipole

question_pool.question: What is the maximum bandwidth permitted by FCC rules for Amateur Radio stations transmitting on USB frequencies in the 60-meter band?
Which of the following limitations apply to transmitter power on every amateur band?

answers.A: Only the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communications should be used
answers.B: Power must be limited to 200 watts when using data transmissions
answers.C: Power should be limited as necessary to avoid interference to another radio service on the frequency
answers.D: Effective radiated power cannot exceed 1500 watts

question_pool.question: What is the limit for transmitter power on the 28 MHz band for a General Class control operator?
What is the limit for transmitter power on the 1.8 MHz band?
What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmission on the 20-meter band?
What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmitted at frequencies below 28 MHz?
What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmitted on the 1.25-meter and 70- centimeter bands?
What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 10-meter band?
What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 2-meter band?
Which of the following is required by the FCC rules when operating in the 60-meter band?

answers.A: If you are using an antenna other than a dipole, you must keep a record of the gain of your antenna
answers.B: You must keep a record of the date, time, frequency, power level, and stations worked
answers.C: You must keep a record of all third-party traffic
answers.D: You must keep a record of the manufacturer of your equipment and the antenna used

question_pool.question: What must be done before using a new digital protocol on the air?

answers.B: Obtain an experimental license from the FCC
answers.C: Publicly document the technical characteristics of the protocol
answers.D: Submit a rule-making proposal to the FCC describing the codes and methods of the technique

question_pool.question: What is the maximum power limit on the 60-meter band?

answers.C: ERP of 100 watts PEP with respect to a dipole
answers.D: ERP of 100 watts PEP with respect to an isotropic antenna

question_pool.question: What measurement is specified by FCC rules that regulate maximum power output?
Who may receive partial credit for the elements represented by an expired Amateur Radio license?

answers.A: Any person who can demonstrate that they once held an FCC-issued General, Advanced, or Amateur Extra class license that was not revoked by the FCC
answers.B: Anyone who held an FCC-issued Amateur Radio license that has been expired for not less than 5 years and not more than 15 years
answers.C: Any person who previously held an amateur license issued by another country, but only if that country has a current reciprocal licensing agreement with the FCC
answers.D: Only persons who once held an FCC issued Novice, Technician, or Technician Plus license

question_pool.question: What license examinations may you administer when you are an accredited VE holding a General class operator license?
On which of the following band segments may you operate if you are a Technician class operator and have a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class privileges?

answers.A: Only the Technician band segments until your upgrade is posted in the FCC database
answers.B: Only on the Technician band segments until your license arrives in the mail
answers.C: On any General or Technician class band segment
answers.D: On any General or Technician class band segment except 30 meters and 60 meters

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a requirement for administering a Technician class license examination?

answers.A: At least three General class or higher VEs must observe the examination
answers.B: At least two General class or higher VEs must be present
answers.C: At least two General class or higher VEs must be present, but only one need be Amateur Extra class
answers.D: At least three VEs of Technician class or higher must observe the examination

question_pool.question: Which of the following must a person have before they can be an administering VE for a Technician class license examination?

answers.A: Notification to the FCC that you want to give an examination
answers.B: Receipt of a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class
answers.C: Possession of a properly obtained telegraphy license
answers.D: An FCC General class or higher license and VEC accreditation

question_pool.question: When must you add the special identifier "AG" after your call sign if you are a Technician class licensee and have a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class operator privileges, but the FCC has not yet posted your upgrade on its website?

answers.A: Whenever you operate using General class frequency privileges
answers.B: Whenever you operate on any amateur frequency
answers.C: Whenever you operate using Technician frequency privileges
answers.D: A special identifier is not required if your General class license application has been filed with the FCC

question_pool.question: Volunteer Examiners are accredited by what organization?
Which of the following criteria must be met for a non-U.S. citizen to be an accredited Volunteer Examiner?

answers.A: The person must be a resident of the U.S. for a minimum of 5 years
answers.B: The person must hold an FCC granted Amateur Radio license of General class or above
answers.C: The person’s home citizenship must be in ITU region 2
answers.D: None of these choices is correct; a non-U.S. citizen cannot be a Volunteer Examiner

question_pool.question: How long is a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) valid for exam element credit?

answers.D: For as long as your current license is valid

question_pool.question: What is the minimum age that one must be to qualify as an accredited Volunteer Examiner?
What is required to obtain a new General Class license after a previously-held license has expired and the two- year grace period has passed?

answers.A: They must have a letter from the FCC showing they once held an amateur or commercial license
answers.B: There are no requirements other than being able to show a copy of the expired license
answers.C: The applicant must be able to produce a copy of a page from a call book published in the U.S. showing his or her name and address
answers.D: The applicant must pass the current Element 2 exam

question_pool.question: Which of the following would disqualify a third party from participating in stating a message over an amateur station?

answers.A: The third party’s amateur license has been revoked and not reinstated
answers.B: The third party is not a U.S. citizen
answers.C: The third party is a licensed amateur
answers.D: The third party is speaking in a language other than English

question_pool.question: When may a 10-meter repeater retransmit the 2-meter signal from a station that has a Technician class control operator?

answers.B: Only if the station on 10-meters is operating under a Special Temporary Authorization allowing such retransmission
answers.C: Only during an FCC-declared general state of communications emergency
answers.D: Only if the 10-meter repeater control operator holds at least a General class license

question_pool.question: What is required to conduct communications with a digital station operating under automatic control outside the automatic control band segments?

answers.A: The station initiating the contact must be under local or remote control
answers.B: The interrogating transmission must be made by another automatically controlled station
answers.C: No third-party traffic may be transmitted
answers.D: The control operator of the interrogating station must hold an Amateur Extra Class license

question_pool.question: Which of the following conditions require a licensed Amateur Radio operator to take specific steps to avoid harmful interference to other users or facilities?

answers.A: When operating within one mile of an FCC Monitoring Station
answers.B: When using a band where the Amateur Service is secondary
answers.C: When a station is transmitting spread spectrum emissions

question_pool.question: What types of messages for a third party in another country may be transmitted by an amateur station?

answers.A: Any message, as long as the amateur operator is not paid
answers.B: Only messages for other licensed amateurs
answers.C: Only messages relating to Amateur Radio or remarks of a personal character, or messages relating to emergencies or disaster relief
answers.D: Any messages, as long as the text of the message is recorded in the station log

question_pool.question: The frequency allocations of which ITU region apply to radio amateurs operating in North and South America?
In what part of the 13-centimeter band may an amateur station communicate with non-licensed Wi-Fi stations?
What is the maximum PEP output allowed for spread spectrum transmissions?
Under what circumstances are messages that are sent via digital modes exempt from Part 97 third-party rules that apply to other modes of communication?
Why should an amateur operator normally avoid transmitting on 14.100, 18.110, 21.150, 24. 930 and 28.200 MHz?

answers.A: A system of propagation beacon stations operates on those frequencies
answers.B: A system of automatic digital stations operates on those frequencies
answers.C: These frequencies are set aside for emergency operations
answers.D: These frequencies are set aside for bulletins from the FCC

question_pool.question: On what bands may automatically controlled stations transmitting RTTY or data emissions communicate with other automatically controlled digital station?

answers.A: On any band segment where digital operation is permitted
answers.B: Anywhere in the non-phone segments of the 10-meter or shorter wavelength bands
answers.C: Only in the non-phone Extra Class segments of the bands
answers.D: Anywhere in the 6-meter or shorter wavelength bands, and in limited segments of some of the HF bands

question_pool.question: Which sideband is most commonly used for voice communications on frequencies of 14 MHz or higher?
Which of the following modes is most commonly used for voice communications on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter bands?
Which of the following is most commonly used for SSB voice communications in the VHF and UHF bands?
Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on the 17-meter and 12-meter bands?
Which mode of voice communication is most commonly used on the HF amateur bands?
Which of the following is an advantage when using single sideband, as compared to other analog voice modes on the HF amateur bands?

answers.B: Less subject to interference from atmospheric static crashes
answers.C: Ease of tuning on receive and immunity to impulse noise
answers.D: Less bandwidth used and greater power efficiency

question_pool.question: Which of the following statements is true of the single sideband voice mode?

answers.A: Only one sideband and the carrier are transmitted; the other sideband is suppressed
answers.B: Only one sideband is transmitted; the other sideband and carrier are suppressed
answers.C: SSB is the only voice mode that is authorized on the 20-meter, 15-meter, and 10-meter amateur bands
answers.D: SSB is the only voice mode that is authorized on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter amateur bands

question_pool.question: What is the recommended way to break in to a phone contact?

answers.A: Say “QRZ” several times, followed by your call sign
answers.D: Say “CQ” followed by the call sign of either station

question_pool.question: Why do most amateur stations use lower sideband on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter bands?

answers.A: Lower sideband is more efficient than upper sideband at these frequencies
answers.B: Lower sideband is the only sideband legal on these frequency bands
answers.C: Because it is fully compatible with an AM detector

question_pool.question: Which of the following statements is true of voice VOX operation versus PTT operation?

answers.A: The received signal is more natural sounding

question_pool.question: Generally, who should respond to a station in the contiguous 48 states who calls “CQ DX”?

answers.A: Any caller is welcome to respond
answers.C: Any stations outside the lower 48 states

question_pool.question: What control is typically adjusted for proper ALC setting on an amateur single sideband transceiver?
Which of the following is true concerning access to frequencies?

answers.B: QSOs in progress always have priority
answers.C: Except during emergencies, no amateur station has priority access to any frequency
answers.D: Contest operations must always yield to non-contest use of frequencies

question_pool.question: What is the first thing you should do if you are communicating with another amateur station and hear a station in distress break in?

answers.A: Continue your communication because you were on the frequency first
answers.B: Acknowledge the station in distress and determine what assistance may be needed

question_pool.question: What is good amateur practice if propagation changes during a contact and you notice interference from other stations on the frequency?

answers.A: Tell the interfering stations to change frequency
answers.B: Report the interference to your local Amateur Auxiliary Coordinator
answers.C: Attempt to resolve the interference problem with the other stations in a mutually acceptable manner

question_pool.question: When selecting a CW transmitting frequency, what minimum separation should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?
When selecting an SSB transmitting frequency, what minimum separation should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?
What is a practical way to avoid harmful interference on an apparently clear frequency before calling CQ on CW or phone?

answers.A: Send “QRL?” on CW, followed by your call sign; or, if using phone, ask if the frequency is in use, followed by your call sign
answers.B: Listen for 2 minutes before calling CQ
answers.C: Send the letter “V” in Morse code several times and listen for a response, or say “test” several times and listen for a response
answers.D: Send “QSY” on CW or if using phone, announce “the frequency is in use,” then give your call sign and listen for a response

question_pool.question: Which of the following complies with good amateur practice when choosing a frequency on which to initiate a call?

answers.A: Check to see if the channel is assigned to another station
answers.B: Identify your station by transmitting your call sign at least 3 times
answers.C: Follow the voluntary band plan for the operating mode you intend to use

question_pool.question: What is the voluntary band plan restriction for U.S. stations transmitting within the 48 contiguous states in the 50.1 to 50.125 MHz band segment?

answers.A: Only contacts with stations not within the 48 contiguous states
answers.B: Only contacts with other stations within the 48 contiguous states

question_pool.question: Who may be the control operator of an amateur station transmitting in RACES to assist relief operations during a disaster?

answers.A: Only a person holding an FCC-issued amateur operator license
answers.B: Only a RACES net control operator
answers.C: A person holding an FCC-issued amateur operator license or an appropriate government official
answers.D: Any control operator when normal communication systems are operational

question_pool.question: When is an amateur station allowed to use any means at its disposal to assist another station in distress?

answers.B: At any time when transmitting in an organized net
answers.C: At any time during an actual emergency

question_pool.question: What frequency should be used to send a distress call?

answers.A: Whichever frequency has the best chance of communicating the distress message
answers.B: Only frequencies authorized for RACES or ARES stations
answers.C: Only frequencies that are within your operating privileges
answers.D: Only frequencies used by police, fire, or emergency medical services

question_pool.question: Which of the following describes full break-in telegraphy (QSK)?

answers.A: Breaking stations send the Morse code prosign “BK”
answers.B: Automatic keyers, instead of hand keys, are used to send Morse code
answers.C: An operator must activate a manual send/receive switch before and after every transmission
answers.D: Transmitting stations can receive between code characters and elements

question_pool.question: What should you do if a CW station sends “QRS?”
What does it mean when a CW operator sends “KN” at the end of a transmission?

answers.C: Listening only for a specific station or stations

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QRL?” mean?

answers.B: “Are you operating full break-in?” or “Can you operate full break-in?”
answers.C: “Are you listening only for a specific station?”
answers.D: “Are you busy?” or “Is this frequency in use?”

question_pool.question: What is the best speed to use when answering a CQ in Morse code?

answers.A: The fastest speed at which you are comfortable copying, but no slower than the CQ
answers.B: The fastest speed at which you are comfortable copying, but no faster than the CQ
answers.C: At the standard calling speed of 10 wpm
answers.D: At the standard calling speed of 5 wpm

question_pool.question: What does the term “zero beat” mean in CW operation?

answers.A: Matching the speed of the transmitting station
answers.B: Operating split to avoid interference on frequency
answers.D: Matching the transmit frequency to the frequency of a received signal

question_pool.question: When sending CW, what does a “C” mean when added to the RST report?

answers.B: Report was read from an S meter rather than estimated

question_pool.question: What prosign is sent to indicate the end of a formal message when using CW?
What does the Q signal “QSL” mean?

answers.B: We have already confirmed by card

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QRN” mean?
What does the Q signal “QRV” mean?

answers.B: There is interference on the frequency
answers.C: I am quitting for the day
answers.D: I am ready to receive messages

question_pool.question: What is the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.A: Amateur volunteers who are formally enlisted to monitor the airwaves for rules violations
answers.B: Amateur volunteers who conduct amateur licensing examinations
answers.C: Amateur volunteers who conduct frequency coordination for amateur VHF repeaters
answers.D: Amateur volunteers who use their station equipment to help civil defense organizations in times of emergency

question_pool.question: Which of the following are objectives of the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.A: To conduct efficient and orderly amateur licensing examinations
answers.B: To encourage amateur radio operators to self-regulate and comply with the rules
answers.C: To coordinate repeaters for efficient and orderly spectrum usage
answers.D: To provide emergency and public safety communications

question_pool.question: What skills learned during hidden transmitter hunts are of help to the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.B: Direction finding used to locate stations violating FCC rules
answers.D: Hunters have an opportunity to transmit on non-amateur frequencies

question_pool.question: Which of the following describes an azimuthal projection map?

answers.A: A map that shows accurate land masses
answers.B: A map that shows true bearings and distances from a particular location
answers.C: A map that shows the angle at which an amateur satellite crosses the equator
answers.D: A map that shows the number of degrees longitude that an amateur satellite appears to move westward at the equator with each orbit

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a good way to indicate on a clear frequency in the HF phone bands that you are looking for a contact with any station?

answers.A: Sign your call sign once, followed by the words “listening for a call” -- if no answer, change frequency and repeat
answers.B: Say “QTC” followed by “this is” and your call sign -- if no answer, change frequency and repeat
answers.C: Repeat “CQ” a few times, followed by “this is,” then your call sign a few times, then pause to listen, repeat as necessary
answers.D: Transmit an unmodulated carried for approximately 10 seconds, followed by “this is” and your call sign, and pause to listen -- repeat as necessary

question_pool.question: How is a directional antenna pointed when making a “long-path” contact with another station?

answers.C: 180 degrees from the station’s short-path heading

question_pool.question: Which of the following are examples of the NATO Phonetic Alphabet?
What is a reason why many amateurs keep a station log?

answers.A: The ITU requires a log of all international contacts
answers.B: The ITU requires a log of all international third-party traffic
answers.C: The log provides evidence of operation needed to renew a license without retest
answers.D: To help with a reply if the FCC requests information

question_pool.question: Which of the following is required when participating in a contest on HF frequencies?

answers.A: Submit a log to the contest sponsor
answers.B: Send a QSL card to the stations worked, or QSL via Logbook of The World
answers.C: Identify your station per normal FCC regulations

question_pool.question: What is QRP operation?
Which of the following is typical of the lower HF frequencies during the summer?

answers.A: Poor propagation at any time of day
answers.B: World-wide propagation during the daylight hours
answers.C: Heavy distortion on signals due to photon absorption
answers.D: High levels of atmospheric noise or “static”

question_pool.question: Which mode is normally used when sending RTTY signals via AFSK with an SSB transmitter?
How can a PACTOR modem or controller be used to determine if the channel is in use by other PACTOR stations?

answers.A: Unplug the data connector temporarily and see if the channel-busy indication is turned off
answers.B: Put the modem or controller in a mode which allows monitoring communications without a connection
answers.C: Transmit UI packets several times and wait to see if there is a response from another PACTOR station
answers.D: Send the message, ”Is this frequency in use?”

question_pool.question: What symptoms may result from other signals interfering with a PACTOR or WINMOR transmission?

answers.C: Failure to establish a connection between stations

question_pool.question: What segment of the 20-meter band is most often used for digital transmissions (avoiding the DX propagation beacons)?
What is the standard sideband used to generate a JT65, JT9, or FT8 digital signal when using AFSK in any amateur band?
What is the most common frequency shift for RTTY emissions in the amateur HF bands?
What segment of the 80-meter band is most commonly used for digital transmissions?
In what segment of the 20-meter band are most PSK31 operations commonly found?

answers.A: At the bottom of the slow-scan TV segment, near 14.230 MHz
answers.B: At the top of the SSB phone segment, near 14.325 MHz
answers.C: In the middle of the CW segment, near 14.100 MHz
answers.D: Below the RTTY segment, near 14.070 MHz

question_pool.question: How do you join a contact between two stations using the PACTOR protocol?

answers.A: Send broadcast packets containing your call sign while in MONITOR mode
answers.B: Transmit a steady carrier until the PACTOR protocol times out and disconnects
answers.C: Joining an existing contact is not possible, PACTOR connections are limited to two stations
answers.D: Send a NAK response continuously so that the sending station must stand by

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a way to establish contact with a digital messaging system gateway station?

answers.A: Send an email to the system control operator
answers.C: Respond when the station broadcasts its SSID
answers.D: Transmit a connect message on the station’s published frequency

question_pool.question: Which of the following is characteristic of the FT8 mode of the WSJT-X family?

answers.A: It is a keyboard-to-keyboard chat mode
answers.C: It is limited to use on VHF
answers.D: Typical exchanges are limited to call signs, grid locators, and signal reports

question_pool.question: Which of the following connectors would be a good choice for a serial data port?
Which communication system sometimes uses the internet to transfer messages?
What could be wrong if you cannot decode an RTTY or other FSK signal even though it is apparently tuned in properly?

answers.A: The mark and space frequencies may be reversed
answers.B: You may have selected the wrong baud rate
answers.C: You may be listening on the wrong sideband

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a requirement when using the FT8 digital mode?

answers.B: Computer time accurate within approximately 1 second

question_pool.question: What is the significance of the sunspot number with regard to HF propagation?

answers.A: Higher sunspot numbers generally indicate a greater probability of good propagation at higher frequencies
answers.B: Lower sunspot numbers generally indicate greater probability of sporadic E propagation
answers.C: A zero sunspot number indicates that radio propagation is not possible on any band
answers.D: A zero sunspot number indicates undisturbed conditions

question_pool.question: What effect does a Sudden Ionospheric Disturbance have on the daytime ionospheric propagation of HF radio waves?

answers.A: It enhances propagation on all HF frequencies
answers.B: It disrupts signals on lower frequencies more than those on higher frequencies
answers.C: It disrupts communications via satellite more than direct communications
answers.D: None, because only areas on the night side of the Earth are affected

question_pool.question: Approximately how long does it take the increased ultraviolet and X-ray radiation from solar flares to affect radio propagation on Earth?
Which of the following are least reliable for long-distance communications during periods of low solar activity?
What is the solar flux index?

answers.A: A measure of the highest frequency that is useful for ionospheric propagation between two points on Earth
answers.B: A count of sunspots that is adjusted for solar emissions
answers.C: Another name for the American sunspot number
answers.D: A measure of solar radiation at 10.7 centimeters wavelength

question_pool.question: What is a geomagnetic storm?

answers.A: A sudden drop in the solar flux index
